What does the `disconnectnode` command do in Verus?
The `disconnectnode` command immediately disconnects from a specified node in Verus.

disconnectnode "node" Immediately disconnects from the specified node. Arguments: 1. "node"   (string, required) The node (see getpeerinfo for nodes) Examples: > verus disconnectnode "192.168.0.6:8233" > curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "disconnectnode", "params": ["192.168.0.6:8233"] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/
What arguments does the `disconnectnode` command require?
The `disconnectnode` command requires one argument: the node to disconnect from, which is a string.

disconnectnode "node" Immediately disconnects from the specified node. Arguments: 1. "node"   (string, required) The node (see getpeerinfo for nodes) Examples: > verus disconnectnode "192.168.0.6:8233" > curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "disconnectnode", "params": ["192.168.0.6:8233"] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/
How can I use the `disconnectnode` command to disconnect from a node with the address "192.168.0.6:8233"?

You can use the `disconnectnode` command to disconnect from a node with the address "192.168.0.6:8233" in two ways:

1. Using the Verus command line:
```
verus disconnectnode "192.168.0.6:8233"
```

2. Using curl:
```
curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "disconnectnode", "params": ["192.168.0.6:8233"] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/
```

Note: Make sure to replace `myusername` with your actual username.

"node"   (string, required) The node (see getpeerinfo for nodes) Examples: > verus disconnectnode "192.168.0.6:8233" > curl --user myusername --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "disconnectnode", "params": ["192.168.0.6:8233"] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:27486/
